definition: A benign inflammatory skin condition characterized by a palisaded or interstitial granulomatous dermatitis primarily driven by macrophages/histiocytes.
clinical: Manifests as annular plaques with a heaped-up border and central atrophy (clearing). There is a female predilection. Clinical variants include localized (few lesions), disseminated (many lesions), perforating, subcutaneous (common in children), and linear. Approximately 50% of cases self-resolve within a couple of years, while others persist.
macroscopic: Annular plaque with minimal surface change and central clearing.
microscopic:
Two main patterns: Palisaded and Interstitial.

1. **Palisaded Pattern:** Histiocytes line up around central zones of necrobiosis (pinkish-blue collagen). The blue hue is due to mucin. In sun-protected skin, multinucleated histiocytes are rare. In sun-damaged skin, multinucleated histiocytes are common and often show elastophagocytosis.
2. **Interstitial Pattern:** More subtle; characterized by increased cellularity (histiocytes) between collagen bundles and associated mucin, without distinct palisading.
differential_diagnosis: Necrobiosis Lipoidica, Rheumatoid Nodule, Necrobiotic Xanthogranuloma, Palisaded Neutrophilic and Granulomatous Dermatitis (PNGD), Scleromyxedema (granulomatous variant).
prognosis_and_prediction: 50% self-resolve; others may be persistent and resistant to treatment.

related_figures.legend: Clinical variants listed and typical clinical course. (Time: 243s)
Clinical appearance of an annular plaque with heaped-up border. (Time: 309s)
Low power view showing the classic palisaded pattern with central mucin. (Time: 325s)
Interstitial variant showing subtle inflammation between collagen bundles. (Time: 478s)
Higher power of interstitial variant showing granular blue mucin. (Time: 525s)

definition: A chronic granulomatous dermatitis, often associated with diabetes, characterized by degeneration of collagen (necrobiosis) and granulomatous inflammation involving the dermis and subcutaneous fat.
clinical: Characteristically presents on the anterior shins (legs) as yellowish-orange atrophic plaques with telangiectasia. Rarely occurs off the legs (e.g., arms/hands). Strong association with diabetes (65% of NL patients have diabetes, though very few diabetics develop NL) and thyroid disease. Can ulcerate and be painful.
microscopic:
Requires a deep punch biopsy as it affects both dermis and subcutaneous fat. 
- **Architecture:** Palisaded granulomatous dermatitis and predominantly septal panniculitis. 
- **Dermis:** Alternating tiers of granulomatous inflammation and acellular 'necrobiosis' (degenerated collagen). Palisading is less distinct than in GA.
- **Cellular Infiltrate:** Multinucleated histiocytes and plasma cells are characteristically present.
differential_diagnosis: Granuloma Annulare (usually purely dermal or subcutaneous, not both; lacks plasma cells), Necrobiotic Xanthogranuloma (has cholesterol clefts and bizarre giant cells).
prognosis_and_prediction: Often chronic; spontaneous resolution is less common than in GA.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation on the hand (unusual site) mimicking GA. (Time: 561s)
Classic clinical appearance on the anterior shins with yellow-orange hue. (Time: 576s)
Low power histology showing involvement of dermis and subcutaneous fat (septal panniculitis). (Time: 683s)
Zones of acellular necrobiosis in the dermis. (Time: 753s)
High power showing multinucleated histiocytes and plasma cells. (Time: 788s)

definition: A rare, systemic histiocytic disorder characterized by destructive granulomatous skin lesions, often in the periorbital region, and associated with paraproteinemia.
clinical: Indurated plaques or nodules, characteristically in a periorbital location. Can ulcerate. Strongly associated with IgG monoclonal gammopathy.
microscopic:
Similar low-power appearance to Necrobiosis Lipoidica (dermal and septal panniculitis involvement with necrobiosis). 
Key distinguishing features:
- **Bizarre Giant Cells:** Very large, multinucleated histiocytes (Touton-like or ring-shaped) containing massive numbers of nuclei (up to 100).
- **Cholesterol Clefts:** Needle-like spaces within the granulomas.
- Presence of plasma cells.
differential_diagnosis: Necrobiosis Lipoidica (lacks cholesterol clefts and such bizarre giant cells), Granuloma Annulare.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic course; associated with underlying hematologic malignancy.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation with periorbital plaques. (Time: 812s)
High power showing extremely large, bizarre multinucleated giant cells. (Time: 913s)
Histology showing cholesterol clefts within the granulomatous inflammation. (Time: 938s)

definition: A subcutaneous nodule composed of palisading granulomas, occurring in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
clinical: Occurs in ~30% of patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis. Firm, non-tender nodules, clinically fixed to the underlying periosteum or fascia. Common on extensor surfaces.
microscopic: Palisaded granulomatous pattern. Deep dermis/subcutis. Central area contains abundant eosinophilic (red/pink) fibrinoid material (fibrinoid necrosis), surrounded by a palisade of histiocytes.
differential_diagnosis: Granuloma Annulare (mucin instead of fibrin), Deep Granuloma Annulare.

related_figures.legend: Histology showing central red/pink fibrinoid material surrounded by palisaded histiocytes. (Time: 980s)

definition: A cutaneous reaction pattern associated with systemic diseases, particularly connective tissue diseases, showing a spectrum from vasculitis to palisaded granulomas.
clinical: Papules or nodules on extensor surfaces (knees, elbows, dorsal hands). Associated with connective tissue diseases (Lupus, RA, Autoimmune arthritis).
pathogenesis: Evolutionary process: Starts as leukocytoclastic vasculitis → evolves into palisaded granulomatous dermatitis.
microscopic:
Features depend on the stage of the lesion. 
- **Early/Active:** Neutrophilic leukocytoclastic vasculitis-like pattern.
- **Developed:** Palisaded granulomas surrounding a center containing neutrophils and basophilic nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia). Dermal collagen degeneration.
prognosis_and_prediction: Often reflects activity of underlying systemic disease.

related_figures.legend: Acral skin biopsy showing nodular areas of inflammation in the dermis. (Time: 1106s)
High power showing central basophilic nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia) surrounded by palisaded histiocytes. (Time: 1145s)

definition: A metabolic disorder characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in tissues (tophi), inciting a granulomatous response.
clinical: Painful nodules (tophi). Classic on toes/fingers/ears, but can occur in unexpected locations. Often not suspected clinically when biopsied from non-acral sites.
microscopic:
Large deposits of amorphous, pale gray material in the dermis (tophus). 
- **Key Artifact:** Formalin dissolves urate crystals, leaving 'shadows' or amorphous gray material. Alcohol fixation preserves the brownish-red crystals.
- **Reaction:** Fine rim of palisaded granulomatous inflammation and multinucleated histiocytes enveloping the deposits.
ancillary_studies: Alcohol fixation (ethanol) to preserve crystals for polarization.

related_figures.legend: Low power showing deposits of pale gray material with a granulomatous rim. (Time: 1193s)
High power showing the 'shadows' of dissolved crystals and multinucleated histiocytes. (Time: 1250s)

definition: A systemic granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, characterized by the formation of non-caseating 'naked' epithelioid granulomas.
clinical: The 'great mimicker.' Presentations include papules, plaques, alopecia (scarring or non-scarring), lupus pernio, and hypopigmented plaques. 30% of systemic sarcoid patients have skin involvement. Erythema Nodosum is a favorable prognostic indicator.
pathogenesis: Immune-mediated. High CD4:CD8 ratio suggests Th1 response.
macroscopic: Variable; red-brown to violaceous papules and plaques.
microscopic:
**Sarcoidal Pattern:** Nodular collections of epithelioid histiocytes (abundant pale cytoplasm, round nuclei). 
- **'Naked' Granulomas:** Characteristically sparse lymphocytic infiltrate around the granulomas (though some variants have more lymphocytes).
- Can occur within tattoos or scars (scar sarcoid).
ancillary_studies: CD4 and CD8 immunostains (High CD4:CD8 ratio is characteristic). Special stains for microorganisms (AFB, Fite, GMS) to rule out infection.
differential_diagnosis: Infectious granulomas (TB, fungal), Foreign body reaction, Granulomatous Rosacea, Granulomatous Dermatitis of Immunodeficiency (inverted CD4:CD8 ratio).

related_figures.legend: Histology showing diffuse sarcoidal inflammation with 'naked' granulomas (sparse lymphocytes). (Time: 1507s)
Sarcoidal reaction within a tattoo. (Time: 1590s)
Comparison of CD8 staining: Sparse in Sarcoidosis (Left) vs. Abundant in Immunodeficiency (Right). (Time: 2914s)

definition: A chronic inflammatory condition of the lips, considered part of the spectrum of orofacial granulomatosis and the Miescher-Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.
clinical: Persistent, firm swelling/induration of the lips. Part of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome triad (Cheilitis, Fissured tongue, Facial nerve palsy). Can overlap with Crohn's disease.
microscopic:
**Clinical-Pathologic Disconnect:** Despite impressive clinical swelling, histology often shows minimal findings. 
- Small, non-caseating granulomas may be seen but are often sparse. 
- Level sections are often required to find a single granuloma.
differential_diagnosis: Sarcoidosis, Crohn's Disease (metastatic), Foreign body reaction.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of significant lip swelling. (Time: 1694s)
Histology often shows sparse or difficult-to-find granulomas despite clinical size. (Time: 1704s)

definition: Cutaneous infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis characterized by tuberculoid granulomas.
clinical: Rare in developed countries. Varied presentation (Lupus Vulgaris, Scrofuloderma, etc.).
microscopic: **Tuberculoid Pattern:** Palisaded or nodular granulomas with central caseous necrosis and neutrophils, surrounded by a lymphocytic rim.
ancillary_studies: AFB (Ziehl-Neelsen) or Fite stains to demonstrate organisms (often scant).

related_figures.legend: Description of the tuberculoid pattern with necrosis. (Time: 1767s)

definition: A benign non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis, most common in children, characterized by accumulation of lipidized histiocytes.
clinical: Erythematous to orange-yellow papules or nodules. Common in children. Multiple lesions in adults warrant workup for hematologic/lymphoproliferative disorders.
microscopic:
Sheet-like or nodular infiltrate of histiocytes. 
- **Touton Giant Cells:** Characteristic multinucleated cells with a central ring of nuclei, a central pink cytoplasmic zone, and a peripheral vacuolated (foamy) lipid-rich zone.

related_figures.legend: Histology showing classic Touton giant cells. (Time: 1934s)

definition: A rare fibromucinous disorder associated with paraproteinemia, typically characterized by mucin and fibrosis, but occasionally presenting as a granulomatous variant.
clinical: Waxy or pearly papules (face/glabella, dorsal hands), diffuse induration/thickening of skin with accentuated folds (resembling leonine facies).
microscopic:
**Classic Pattern:** Mucin deposition, fibrosis, and increased proliferation of plump fibroblasts (CD34+). 
**Granulomatous Variant:** Approximately 25% of biopsies show an Interstitial Granulomatous Dermatitis pattern mimicking Interstitial GA (interstitial histiocytes + mucin) rather than the classic fibrosis.
ancillary_studies: CD68 (histiocytes), Alcian Blue or Colloidal Iron (mucin), CD34 (fibroblasts).
differential_diagnosis: Interstitial Granuloma Annulare, Leprosy, Mycosis Fungoides.

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance showing waxy papules and accentuated skin folds on the face. (Time: 2056s)
Histology showing interstitial histiocytes (CD68+) and mucin (Alcian Blue), mimicking Interstitial GA. (Time: 2214s)
Classic histology with abundant mucin and increased fibroblasts. (Time: 2386s)

definition: A variant of Lichen Sclerosus exhibiting granulomatous inflammation in addition to the classic sclerosing features.
clinical: Atrophic plaques with 'cigarette paper' wrinkling. Can occur in genital or extra-genital sites.
pathogenesis: Variant of LS, possibly related to ruptured follicles/milia or intrinsic to the inflammation.
microscopic:
Upper dermis shows classic LS features: Hyperkeratosis, epidermal atrophy, and a band of dermal sclerosis/hyalinization. 
- **Granulomatous Component:** Deeper to the sclerosis, there is a granulomatous infiltrate containing multinucleated giant cells and elastophagocytosis.

related_figures.legend: Histology showing classic LS features (sclerosis, atrophy) with an underlying granulomatous infiltrate. (Time: 2480s)
High power showing multinucleated histiocytes. (Time: 2565s)
Clinical appearance of extragenital LS. (Time: 2574s)

definition: A granulomatous eruption occurring in patients with primary immunodeficiencies (e.g., CVID, Ataxia Telangiectasia) or other immunocompromised states.
clinical: Lesions often have surface changes (crust/scale), unlike classic GA/Sarcoid. Occurs in CVID, Ataxia Telangiectasia, and other immunodeficiencies.
pathogenesis: Immune dysregulation. Rubella virus has been identified in some lesions.
microscopic:
Variable histology: Can be Palisaded, Sarcoidal, or Nondescript granulomatous dermatitis. 
- **Key Immunophenotype:** Inverted CD4:CD8 ratio (CD8 predominant), contrasting with Sarcoidosis (CD4 predominant).
ancillary_studies: CD4 and CD8 immunostains (show CD8 > CD4). PCR/stains for Rubella or other viruses may be considered.

related_figures.legend: Immunostaining showing CD8 predominance in Immunodeficiency (Right) vs paucity in Sarcoid (Left). (Time: 2914s)
Example showing a palisaded pattern in an immunodeficient patient. (Time: 2942s)
